seg.seg: ... having looked at ... Woman (and) female being have become a stain on moral conduct. Where ...
(does not) remain (pure). Starting with all that, Siddhārtha tells sins of yours by the hundreds.
Women have carried Siddhārtha in their womb, women have given birth to him, women have raised him.
he blames? || Then some women say: Having seen the reason, the Buddhas (blame the defects) of some living beings.
Therefore do not (send) us back from hearing the Law because of words of the arrogant Śākyas!
... the becoming revealed of (six rare) things. We have been liberated concerning the eight chanceless places.
We have come (to meet the Buddha-god the teacher). May he not put blame on us! Therefore let us go to listen to the Law!
He will not put blame on us, let us therefore go to listen to the law!
The (Śākya) women went to the Buddha-god the teacher. The Buddha-god the teacher (understood) the thought of the women.
... (ﬁve) virtues of women: They do not make the house empty, the accumulated possessions ...
... together with them the men enjoy the pleasure of beauty and pleasant talk. From women, Buddhas, Pratyekabuddhas, ... (have come into the world).
Having heard that, and having become glad, the women say: Shame on the denouncers, who ...
Shame be on the denouncers, who … (cf 157)
(who) was the paragon of virtue in the world, he the Buddha-god teacher speaks to us in every way.
... we will hear the Law! || Thereupon the Buddha-god the teacher (preached the Law) in such a way to the Śākya women.
(the second time), at the teaching of the Law, sixty thousand obtained the glory. The third time, at the teaching of the Law, forty thousand ...
... proﬁt came their way, as follows: three times at the teaching of the Law ...

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 3a11-4a15. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 158.
The restored collocation (seni)k śont is the nominative feminine plural of TA senik śo, for which see 322; cf. also TB senik śawa (: a3).
The beginning of this leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 3, 3 a11, and the last line to 4 a15.
This sentence is not matched exactly by the Uyghur text, cf. MaitrHami 3, 3 a16-17.
śārwres is the accusative plural masculine of TA śārwär*, the equivalent of TB śarware 'arrogant'; cf. MaitrHami 3, 3 b1-2.
In this context, the formsäs cannot be the nominative singular masculine of the demonstrative. It may be a postposition governing the locative, to be translated tentatively ‘with respect to’.

The collocation naṣ nākäm in : b6 suggests that naṣ may be very close in meaning to nākäm ‘blame’. In the present passage, naṣ occurs in combination with the verb nāk-; it may be used as a quasi internal object of ‘to blame’.

The form ṣtākkrukkeśśi is genitive plural, probably of a deverbative compound similar in structure to TA ri-pāṣe ‘protector of the city’. The ﬁrst element ṣtāk may permit an analysis as ā-case extended by emphatic -k of ṣät ‘downwards’; it cannot be decided whether the verb stem involved is to be identiﬁed as kruk- or ruk-. If one wants to consider the possibility that -kk- in the verbal part of the compound was assimilated to the ﬁrst occurrence of -kk-, -rukke* could be derived from a -rutke*, on the root rutk- ‘fortbewegen’, which would mean that the meaning of the compound could be reconstructed as ‘one who is moving someone down’.
pkāk: Schmidt's (281) correction to p_ukāk cannot be confirmed.
